speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: SCENE IV. The same. Before the palace.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter SATURNINUS, TAMORA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON,  Lords, and others; SATURNINUS with the arrows in his hand that TITUS shot

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Why, lords, what wrongs are these! was ever seen

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: An emperor in Rome thus overborne,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Troubled, confronted thus; and, for the extent

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Of egal justice, used in such contempt?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: My lords, you know, as know the mightful gods,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: However these disturbers of our peace

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Buz in the people's ears, there nought hath pass'd,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But even with law, against the willful sons

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Of old Andronicus. And what an if

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: His sorrows have so overwhelm'd his wits,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Shall we be thus afflicted in his wreaks,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: His fits, his frenzy, and his bitterness?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And now he writes to heaven for his redress:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: See, here's to Jove, and this to Mercury;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: This to Apollo; this to the god of war;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sweet scrolls to fly about the streets of Rome!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What's this but libelling against the senate,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And blazoning our injustice every where?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: A goodly humour, is it not, my lords?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: As who would say, in Rome no justice were.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But if I live, his feigned ecstasies

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Shall be no shelter to these outrages:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But he and his shall know that justice lives

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: In Saturninus' health, whom, if she sleep,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: He'll so awake as she in fury shall

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Cut off the proud'st conspirator that lives.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: My gracious lord, my lovely Saturnine,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Lord of my life, commander of my thoughts,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Calm thee, and bear the faults of Titus' age,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The effects of sorrow for his valiant sons,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Whose loss hath pierced him deep and scarr'd his heart;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And rather comfort his distressed plight

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Than prosecute the meanest or the best

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: For these contempts.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Aside

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Why, thus it shall become

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: High-witted Tamora to gloze with all:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But, Titus, I have touched thee to the quick,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Thy life-blood out: if Aaron now be wise,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Then is all safe, the anchor's in the port.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Enter Clown

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: How now, good fellow! wouldst thou speak with us?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Yea, forsooth, an your mistership be emperial.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Empress I am, but yonder sits the emperor.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: 'Tis he. God and Saint Stephen give you good den:

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I have brought you a letter and a couple of pigeons here.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: SATURNINUS reads the letter

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Go, take him away, and hang him presently.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: How much money must I have?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Come, sirrah, you must be hanged.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Hanged! by'r lady, then I have brought up a neck to

speaker: Clown
text_entry: a fair end.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exit, guarded

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Despiteful and intolerable wrongs!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Shall I endure this monstrous villany?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I know from whence this same device proceeds:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: May this be borne?--as if his traitorous sons,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That died by law for murder of our brother,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Have by my means been butcher'd wrongfully!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Go, drag the villain hither by the hair;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Nor age nor honour shall shape privilege:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: For this proud mock I'll be thy slaughterman;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sly frantic wretch, that holp'st to make me great,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: In hope thyself should govern Rome and me.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Enter AEMILIUS

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What news with thee, AEmilius?

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Arm, arm, my lord;--Rome never had more cause.

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: The Goths have gather'd head; and with a power

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: high-resolved men, bent to the spoil,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: They hither march amain, under conduct

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Of Lucius, son to old Andronicus;

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Who threats, in course of this revenge, to do

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: As much as ever Coriolanus did.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Is warlike Lucius general of the Goths?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: These tidings nip me, and I hang the head

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: As flowers with frost or grass beat down with storms:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Ay, now begin our sorrows to approach:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: 'Tis he the common people love so much;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Myself hath often over-heard them say,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: When I have walked like a private man,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That Lucius' banishment was wrongfully,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And they have wish'd that Lucius were their emperor.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Why should you fear? is not your city strong?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Ay, but the citizens favor Lucius,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And will revolt from me to succor him.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: King, be thy thoughts imperious, like thy name.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Is the sun dimm'd, that gnats do fly in it?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The eagle suffers little birds to sing,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And is not careful what they mean thereby,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Knowing that with the shadow of his wings

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: He can at pleasure stint their melody:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Even so mayst thou the giddy men of Rome.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Then cheer thy spirit : for know, thou emperor,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I will enchant the old Andronicus

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: With words more sweet, and yet more dangerous,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Than baits to fish, or honey-stalks to sheep,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: When as the one is wounded with the bait,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The other rotted with delicious feed.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But he will not entreat his son for us.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: If Tamora entreat him, then he will:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: For I can smooth and fill his aged ear

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: With golden promises; that, were his heart

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Almost impregnable, his old ears deaf,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Yet should both ear and heart obey my tongue.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To AEmilius

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Go thou before, be our ambassador:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Say that the emperor requests a parley

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Of warlike Lucius, and appoint the meeting

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Even at his father's house, the old Andronicus.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: AEmilius, do this message honourably:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And if he stand on hostage for his safety,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Bid him demand what pledge will please him best.

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Your bidding shall I do effectually.

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Now will I to that old Andronicus;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And temper him with all the art I have,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To pluck proud Lucius from the warlike Goths.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And now, sweet emperor, be blithe again,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And bury all thy fear in my devices.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Then go successantly, and plead to him.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Exeunt
